Podle těch čísel je dost velká pravděpodobnost, že tam ty e-maily stále jsou. Níže je popis přenosu na nový počítač, ale postup lze použít i pro přenos/kopírování na tentýž počítač.

Nejjednodušší způsob přenosu e-mailů Thunderbirdu je zkopírovat a přenést celý profilový adresář ze starého počítače na nový pomocí externího média, jako je USB disk. Před kopírováním vždy ukončete Thunderbird. Na novém počítači nainstalujte Thunderbird a poté přeneste zkopírovanou složku profilu do správného umístění. Postup přenosu celého profilu (nejjednodušší metoda) Ukončete Thunderbird: na původním počítači. Najděte složku profilu: na svém počítači: Windows Vista a novější: C:\Users\jméno_uživatele\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird Windows XP: C:\Documents and Settings\jméno_uživatele\Data Aplikací\Thunderbird Mac OS X: ~/Library/Thunderbird/Profiles/ Linux: ~/.thunderbird/ Zkopírujte: celou složku Thunderbird na externí paměťové médium (např. USB disk, externí pevný disk). Na novém počítači: nejprve nainstalujte Thunderbird. Ukončete Thunderbird: na novém počítači (pokud se spustil automaticky). Vložte: zkopírovanou složku profilu z externího média do příslušné složky na novém počítači, kde jste složku Thunderbird našli v kroku 2. Případně můžete pomocí Správce profilů vytvořit nový profil a pak do jeho složky vložit soubory ze zálohy. Tj. z toho profilu, kde jsou ty složky s e-maily. Spusťte Thunderbird: na novém počítači. Budou se vám zobrazovat e-maily, účty a nastavení ze starého počítače. Alternativní postup (pomocí pluginu) Nainstalujte si doplněk: ImportExportTools NG do Thunderbirdu na původním počítači. https://services.addons.thunderbird.net/CS/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/ Exportujte: zprávy nebo celý profil pomocí tohoto doplňku. Přeneste soubory: na nový počítač a importujte je pomocí doplňku. Tento postup je ideální, pokud nechcete přenášet celý profil, ale pouze vybrané zprávy nebo složky.

Most of the time, such a problem is due to the wrong server settings or username or password being used. That is why I've been asking about your server settings and e-mail server provider. If you tell me who your e-mail service provider is, I can help ensure that you are using the right settings.

Were you been able to send and receive messages before you changed your password? Or are you setting up your account in Thunderbird for the first time?

How did you change your password? Some people "change" their password in Thunderbird. That does not work. You must change your password at the website of your e-mail service provider, then use the new password in Thunderbird.

Can you log into the mail system at your e-mail service provider's website by using your new password?

Who is your e-mail service provider?

Please go into account settings in Thunderbird. Click on the name of your account in the panel on the left. Click on "Edit outgoing server" on the right. Report here all the data that appears in the next window (server name, port, et cet.). For your own use, note the username. Do not report the username here. This information is for the outgoing server. It allows you to send messages from Thunderbird.

Then click on "Server Settings" in the panel on the left. Note the data on the right. Report here the server type, the server name, the port, the connection security, and the authentication method. For your own use, note the username. Do not report the username here. This information is for the incoming server. It allows you to receive messages in Thunderbird.

If, as before, you still do not want to answer my questions, here's what you should do:

If you cannot access the mail system at your e-mail service provider's website with your new password, then you have the wrong password and you must re-set it at your e-mail service provider's website. Then enter the new password in Thunderbird when you are asked for it.

If you can access the mail system at your e-mail service provider's website with your new password, then you must find out what settings your e-mail service provider uses for the incoming and outgoing server, including username, and ensure that you are using all the right settings in Thunderbird. My instructions earlier in this message tell you how to access that information in Thunderbird.

Your e-mail service provider may require that what is sometimes called an "app-specific" password or a "security" password be used in Thunderbird in place of your regular password. If so, you must generate that password at the website of your e-mail service provider, then use it in Thunderbird.

content:
Good morning, Renee,

A size of 1.6 GB indicates many thousands of messages. Using my own folders as a reference, I calculate 25,000 - 35,000 messages. (I don't store attachments with messages. If you do, you will have fewer messages in 1.6 GB than I do.) That's good news. Let us hope now that they can be recovered.

Before doing anything else, I would learn with certainty whether or not a recent back-up copy of my profile exists.

I would also make a back-up copy of my profile. The easiest way to do that on a Mac is to drag the profile folder to an external drive. If you do not have an external drive, you should get one, at least a large-capacity USB "thumb" drive that can hold a copy of all your important documents and data, including your Thunderbird profile. (You should also use Time Machine to back up your whole hard drive regularly, except for some files that do not need to be backed up, which you can exclude.)

When you are ready to attempt to recover the messages in that inbox file, here are the steps that I would take:

  1. Copy that inbox file from the Thunderbird profile to the desktop. The easiest way to do that on a Mac is to option-drag the file from the profile folder to the desktop. You know now (see above) how to get to your profile folder, and you seem to know how to drill down in it to the 1.6 GB file. Make sure that you hold the option key down before you click and drag and keep it held down until the you have released the file on the desktop.
  2. Rename the file on the desktop to differentiate it from your inbox. I might name it, full of hope, "Recovered inbox".
  3. Install the excellent Thunderbird add-on ImportExportToolsNG. "Tools" (menu) > "Add-ons and Themes", search for "ImportExportToolsNG", click the "Add to Thunderbird" button when you find it.
  4. Return to the main Thunderbird window that shows the folder pane and e-mail messages.
  5. "View" (menu) > Toolbars. Make sure that "Status Bar" is checked. If it is not, select it.
  6. Right click on "Local Folders" in the folder pane. You should see a drop-down menu. At the bottom of the menu should be an option for "importExportToolsNG". Select it. The menu will then cascade to show more options. At the next level, select "Import mbox files". At the next level, select "Individual mbox files".
  7. You should then see a file selection window. In that window, navigate to your desktop and select the inbox file that you renamed.
  8. If ImportExportToolsNG is able to read the file, it will need a few minutes, depending on the speed of your computer, to import the messages. Since you ensured that "Status Bar" is enabled, you can monitor the progress at the bottom of Thunderbird's main window.
  9. In the best case, ImportExportToolsNG will import 25,000 - 35,000 messages and you will be on your way to making everything right again. I don't know how much hope we should have because I don't know what the problem is with your inbox. I am hoping for the best.

Please stop and ask questions if you have difficulty with anything.

Oh, we also must still worry about what caused this problem because it could occur again. I'm sorry that I don't have a recommendation. I assume that your version 140 is "140esr". Is that right? You could switch to the monthly release channel. It's possible that it will not have whatever caused this problem. But that is only a hope. It's also possible that it has the same problem or even new problems. You can learn about release channels here: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/choosing-thunderbird-release-channel

If you want to make a change, you may want to ask for guidance here before starting. Please don't hesitate.

One other thought: 1.6 GB is rather large for a single folder. Thunderbird should be able to handle it, but I can imagine more problems with a folder of that size than with smaller folders. content:
1. „Centrum.cz mi nedovoluje poslat více e-mailů po sobě“ Centrum.cz (a obecně české freemailové služby jako Seznam.cz, Email.cz nebo Post.cz) mají poměrně přísné limity a ochrany proti zneužití, které mohou vést k přesně těmto problémům.

Důvody:

  • Antispamová ochrana: Pokud odešleš více e-mailů krátce po sobě (např. několik během pár minut), Centrum.cz to může vyhodnotit jako pokus o hromadné rozesílání nevyžádané pošty (spam).
  • Dočasné limity serveru: Freemailové služby často omezují počet e-mailů, které může běžný uživatel odeslat za určitý čas (např. 10–20 zpráv za 10 minut nebo 100–200 denně).
  • Technická ochrana účtu: Pokud systém zaznamená podezřelou aktivitu (např. mnoho příjemců, stejné tělo zprávy, velký objem odeslaných dat), může dočasně zablokovat odesílání, aby předešel zneužití účtu spamery.

2. „Centrum.cz nedovolí odeslat e-mail s více přílohami“

Důvody:

  • Limit velikosti e-mailu: Centrum.cz má limit na celkovou velikost odchozí zprávy (včetně příloh), typicky 20 MB. Pokud máš více příloh, může celkový objem (včetně kódování) tento limit snadno překročit.
  • Bezpečnostní filtry: Některé typy příloh (např. .exe, .bat, .zip s vnořenými spustitelnými soubory) jsou automaticky blokovány.
  • Systémová omezení: Někdy rozhraní webmailu dovoluje jen určitý počet příloh (např. max. 10 najednou).

  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
